subject: Re: [junit] black box or white box?
msgSnippet: ... How do you know that an inplementation cannot break? By looking at it I assume... ... refactoring When your tests only use the public interfaces they
messageBody:
> * Test everything that could possibly break in the current implementation

How do you know that an inplementation cannot break? By looking at it I
assume...

> * Are sufficiently implementation-independent to support easier
refactoring

When your tests only use the public interfaces they usually don't break
during refactoring. They might become redundant, i.e. worthless, when you
test a special case which is no special case in the new refactored
implementation any more.

> * Run quickly, are small, easy to read...
>
> I realize that these are competing forces, so the challenge is striking
the
> right balance. I find my life difficult when my tests get in the way of my
> refactorings... tests that have intimate knowledge of the implementation
tend
> to be refactoring-resistant. I tend away from them if I can.

That's a very food heuristic for deciding if it's worth writing a test or
not: asking if the test will probably stay around with the next
functionality or not. This is my biggest concern I have with doing
endo-testing using mock objects.

Where do you think our views still differ? Defining the "real" meaning of a
term (black-box) seems no essential difference to me. It's interesting but
merely of academic value.

Johannes
